part of one of the greatest

Negativity breeds and has

So as you start SEAL training,
one of the major hurdles

213.85.text:
BUD/S is the course that every

and it stands for Basic
Underwater Demolition SEAL

221.45.text:
And it's the one that you

224.71.text: and it's in a lot of books.

229.24.text:
in the world from the
first day to the end.

233.06.text:
Now, there's about three or four
months prior to the first day

237.29.text:
But once you start,
it's 26 weeks.

242.74.text:
The beginning of it,
the first 9 to 10 weeks

246.07.text:
So it's like, the
workout starts at 5:00

249.10.text:
AM, which means you've
got up at 4:00 or whatever

251.14.text:
and class gets together,
gets a full headcount.

255.69.text:
You work until about
6:30, go to breakfast.

257.49.text:
Then you come
back, and you'll do

259.21.text:
like two hours of
log workouts, which

261.93.text:

263.80.text:
where you're working
out with six guys each

265.60.text:
holding a log doing
different drills,

269.08.text:
that if one guy doesn't pull his

273.66.text:
And then you'll rest and

275.62.text:
You have a seven-mile

278.74.text:
in the soft sand, followed
by a two-mile timed swim

282.02.text:
Then you'd run to
the pool, which

283.39.text:
is a mile and a half away, swim
there, get tied up, thrown in,

287.50.text:
You do this all day
long every single day.

289.59.text:
And something funny, too,

292.90.text:
is, from where you do these
workouts to the galley--

298.96.text:
So no matter what, you're
running six miles a day

304.06.text:
Food is 300 feet
away at all times.

307.59.text: But yeah, it's a tough course.

309.76.text:
One of the hardest parts

It's so bad they keep you

339.63.text:

433.64.text:
We'd never really been to war

438.07.text:
and we'd never been
in a war like this,

439.79.text:
a certain counterinsurgency-type

445.27.text:

447.61.text:

450.97.text:

453.04.text: You need them to like you.

454.12.text:
And a lot of people
say hearts and minds.

459.83.text: We were trying to be innovative.

461.36.text:
And we realized that if we
can make their lives better,

464.89.text: we can get them on our team.

466.28.text:
And how do you make

469.03.text:
You want to help them

470.57.text: So you've got to give him a job.

471.43.text:
So we would find
a spot with some

472.83.text:
of the money we

474.33.text: get what's called a safe house.

then you hire first
security-- so you actually

481.00.text:

You hire plumbers,

You're hiring cooks,
hiring all kinds of stuff--

491.18.text:
And then we actually expanded

494.97.text:
shopping in the bazaars,
eating at the restaurants

497.05.text:
in Afghanistan, getting
to know the neighbors

500.89.text:
and their children so that if

505.41.text:
with their, kids they're going

507.91.text:
they can from people

Because it's not just

515.02.text:
People that go to the internet

they're hearing stuff
from other people.

They're talking to
their cousins who

522.60.text:
hear from the Taliban,

524.52.text: So it was working for a while.

525.77.text:
We-- I felt like we
had it won over there

530.05.text:
The issue is a lot of
government agencies,

535.42.text:
And they love to say this is

538.06.text:
And they do what's

539.24.text:

It worked in Europe
in World War II.

547.51.text:
And just, I remember

550.06.text: how it's not going to work.

552.11.text:
Didn't even explain it to the

559.36.text:
And they decided-- this is like

564.10.text:
Well, let's get a base

565.90.text:
and we'll pull everyone
out of the city

568.96.text:
And then the only

571.32.text:

573.82.text:
so he's driving fast

575.59.text:
And if you want to shop,

577.63.text:

then they can sell,

580.87.text:
but now they upped

588.07.text:
You sort of see

589.72.text:
You're going to become

591.76.text:
and that's how you get

594.33.text:
So it was interesting

596.20.text:
and actually kind of a
business-like team building

601.09.text:
and almost local leadership,

605.13.text:
That's kind of where

ROB O'NEILL: That was

one of my tactics

only time the plan exists

721.24.text:

729.85.text:
A prime example was

in the country

because we knew

738.16.text:

741.71.text:

744.25.text:
and then eat something,

746.29.text:
And when we were done at 11:30,

749.60.text: and we stand around a table--

751.30.text:
perfect model of the thing--
and talk about the perfect

753.79.text:
plan till we're talking

755.62.text:
Then we came up with

759.22.text:
But we know the perfect

761.20.text:
And then one night we're

763.06.text:
and the boss said OK, what's the

765.70.text:
And the youngest guy
in the room said, well,

767.89.text:
the helicopter could

770.35.text:
And he pointed right
there, and everyone kind of

771.55.text:
looked at him like, you

775.47.text:
And he goes, I don't know, let's

779.45.text:
The helicopter
crashed, and none of us

781.03.text:
knew it except the
guys that crashed.

784.16.text: We were in the other one.

787.99.text:
I always ask people, are
you teaching your people

791.09.text:
how to do their jobs
or are you trying

792.67.text: to do their job for them?

794.84.text:
We were big believers in making
sure our guys are prepared,

797.86.text:
teaching them exactly what we
think they need to do, and then

801.19.text: Let them do what they should do.

806.05.text:
We thought that you can do
three major tasks at once.

809.47.text:
If you get to four and
five, you'll lose something.

814.61.text:
So you need to hand those
tasks to someone else

816.61.text:
knowing that they'll
get to three or four

818.01.text:
and then hand the fourth one
to another part of the team.

820.12.text:
And just the micromanagement
slows everything down,

823.86.text:
which is the opposite of

826.00.text:
That's kind of the
way we tried to roll.

829.75.text:
so night of, you're

Can you tell us what some

834.18.text:
I imagine it had to

836.49.text:
It's maybe the most important

"American Sniper,"

869.50.text:
that was the one where we

872.70.text:
We knew that we were

874.80.text:
captured, which in
that part of the world

878.67.text:
So we went into it

884.16.text:
that the probability of
dying, very, very high.

888.07.text:
To the point where we were
actually having conversations

890.40.text:
about, OK, we've got to
think about how are we

894.72.text: I think I was like 35 years old.

896.25.text:
And I was like,
well, if I don't go

898.18.text:
on this, what if when I'm
70, I look back and just

900.26.text:
have nothing but regret because

902.81.text: I need to go on this mission.

904.02.text:
I need to accept the fact

909.08.text:
When we were going up

910.95.text:
the guy who ended up
being in front of me--

912.78.text:
the first guy up the
stairs and I was second--

917.01.text:
he said, don't get me wrong, I'm

921.81.text:
But if we know we're going

927.46.text:
I'd want a wargame

929.92.text:
But then the conversation

931.63.text:

933.34.text:

935.38.text:

938.81.text:
at elementary school
on a Tuesday morning

941.37.text:
and 45 minutes later she

943.37.text:
of a skyscraper because
that was a better

946.88.text:
And her last gesture

948.47.text:
was holding her skirt down
so no one saw her underwear

952.22.text:
She didn't want
to do either one,

953.60.text:
and she wasn't supposed

956.00.text:
And that's the kind of

958.90.text:

966.52.text:
You have the last

970.75.text:
This is probably the

in the playpen, but you're

978.57.text:
So very, very focused, very

993.60.text:
because you've got to figure,

agencies up to the White House,

1000.97.text:
he made the call, I don't

And he did that knowing
that, if we fail,

1008.44.text:
I mean, obviously, he's

1012.46.text:
He's not going to
win a second term.

1013.96.text:
There's a thing called

1015.67.text:
when we tried to rescue

1017.77.text:
complete failure, horrible

1035.57.text:
along with all the
other stuff that

1038.35.text:
And then we were thinking about

if I'm going to get starstruck,

1055.60.text:
We had an issue

you want to know

2089.09.text:
what a fight in the
mountains of Afghanistan

2093.71.text: I think they did a good job.

2095.33.text:
Like I said, "Zero Dark
Thirty" did an excellent job

2102.23.text: and how their passion found him.

2106.14.text:
"American Sniper"
did a really good job

2107.99.text:
showing some of the
post-traumatic effects

2110.42.text:
of the families,
excellent job with that.

2112.16.text:
Didn't like the fake
baby in that one.

2113.39.text: Did you see the fake baby?

2124.25.text:
"Lone Survivor," excellent,
like I just mentioned.

2126.39.text: And then what was the other one?

2127.64.text:
SPEAKER: You're not
a Tom Hanks fan.

2130.82.text:
No, that was a good
movie because they

2135.51.text:
You'll notice,
when the guys took

2136.88.text:
the shots, the first thing,
they did took the shots,

2139.92.text:
and they pulled their
bipods up and left.

2144.54.text:
Because when that
was over, I remember

2146.53.text:
talking to the snipers--
this was before bin Laden--

2148.70.text:
so I was like, you realize
this is the-- you just

2150.79.text:
did like the single greatest
thing in the history

2154.70.text:
And the sniper looked at me
and said, cool, can we go home?

2157.20.text: That's just the way he acted.

2158.79.text:
They asked me how
accurate that movie is.

2160.82.text:
And I said, depends
on who's asking.

2162.68.text:
Like, in a forum
here, 70% accurate.

2165.86.text:
Happy hour, if a lady
asked me, 100% accurate.

2172.12.text:
SPEAKER: So in a
few minutes, we're

2173.58.text:
going to go to Q&A
in the audience.

2175.26.text:
So if anyone wants to
step up to the mics,

2177.05.text:
if you have any
questions, feel free.

2179.30.text:
While we're waiting
for that, Rob,

2180.77.text:
could you tell us about the
creative process for the book?

2185.33.text:
Was that a new hurdle for
you writing in that form,

2188.47.text:
trying to recall all these
missions for so many years?

2191.47.text:
It was new, but I'd
been keeping a journal

2195.74.text:
since training just because it
seemed like the thing to do.

2198.30.text:
Even though there
wasn't a lot going on,

2199.46.text:
I always thought maybe if
there's a good story here,

2202.94.text:
So I was able to go through
a lot of my old stuff

2204.98.text: and recall a lot of stuff.

2206.07.text:
And I actually talked to
some of my guys before it.

2208.40.text:
And then just to sit down and go
through and kind of break it--

2213.68.text:
It came out to like 26
or something like that.

2215.97.text:
But just interesting stories,
different parts of life.

2219.38.text:
The creative process
was good because it

2223.41.text:
I had some help
writing it, obviously,

2226.16.text:
So they could dot the i's
and all the good stuff.

2231.00.text:
So I think we'll
go to the audience

2234.42.text:
AUDIENCE: So you talked a little
bit about transitioning people

2238.37.text:
I'm wondering what
parts of life as a SEAL,

2242.92.text:
I mean, obviously
not the big stuff--

2244.46.text:
but what small elements of
management or team building

2247.68.text:
do you think really,
really translate,

2249.29.text:
and anyone can take away
when they're building a team?

2254.95.text:
We were big into saying
you take care of your gear,

2257.30.text: your gear takes care of you.

2258.58.text:
So the whole thing is like,
when you're done with something,

2261.08.text:
clean it now and do everything
like you'd do anything.

2263.35.text:
And then keep an inventory
of what you've got,

2265.27.text:
and then also know where your
friend's stuff is in case

2267.95.text:
Because we would
keep our stuff in--

2273.02.text:
And we would keep our
lockers in certain bags.

2274.94.text:
And the bags are
full of gear designed

2277.65.text:
So you have these different
bags for like a water jump,

2279.98.text:
land jump, high-altitude diving,
desert, jungle, all that stuff.

2284.00.text:
And you just want to
keep care of your stuff

2285.83.text:
because you're going to need
a lot of different stuff

2288.50.text:
in the jungle than you will on
a night jump into Afghanistan

2293.49.text:
So just the accountability
of your gear and knowing

2296.09.text:
And then the two beer
limit was really good.

2301.13.text:
AUDIENCE: Do you have
any tips for civilians

2303.35.text:
for building up that mental
dexterity that you talk about?

2306.17.text:
You know, that
focus, that ability

2309.37.text:
to push out that negativity
and really focus on the goal?

2316.34.text:
I mean, the biggest
one is the realization

2318.48.text:
that you're probably
not going to succeed

2323.69.text:
One of my legitimate answers
to that, too, it's funny--

2326.93.text:
I don't keep them mean
to keep making jokes--

2329.90.text:
but I would say
stay off Facebook

2331.27.text:
because that's where
the negativity is.

2333.34.text:
That just struck me as funny
that comes to mind here again.

2342.98.text:
You're not going to
make it every time.

2346.05.text:
You know, chances
are what you were

2349.04.text:
I didn't mention all this stuff
before, but just keep at it.

2352.49.text:
And if you want to be good at
anything, do it 1,000 times.

2355.23.text:
Like people will say, how
do I get better pull-ups?

2359.40.text:
SPEAKER: So Rob, you actually
have an interesting story

2363.18.text:
Can you tell us about your
dad and the free throws story?

2366.64.text:
We, my father and I,
played basketball everyday.

2372.29.text:
And one of our rules
is when my season

2375.50.text:
would end with whatever,
junior high or high school,

2379.34.text:
And we'd play two to
three hours a day.

2381.08.text:
But one of our rules is, no
matter, as soon as we finish,

2384.55.text:
we don't get to
leave until one of us

2386.09.text: makes 20 free throws in a row.

2388.13.text:
So it would start with a make,
and then one guy rebounds.

2390.51.text:
You start with a make, and
then you shoot until you miss.

2394.05.text:
And so it was a 20 to
leave the gym every day,

2397.31.text:
but then it was 20
to get a steak dinner

2400.79.text: at the Derby in Butte, Montana.

2402.89.text:
But once you got the steak,
then it moved up by 25.

2405.02.text:
So it's 20 to leave the
gym, then 25 for a steak.

2409.76.text:
And we got to a point
where my father,

2412.73.text:
I think he made
92 in a row, which

2415.37.text:
was the family record for
a week because I made 105.

2419.91.text:
But again, that's just
the way we learned.

2421.66.text:
That's how we learned
how to shoot free

2423.28.text:
throws, how to shoot weapons,
just repetition, repetition.

2428.88.text: I hope I answered your question.

2432.27.text:
SPEAKER: Next question
on the right here.

2434.69.text:
This is something I've
been really curious about.

2436.73.text:
I mean, with you and
the other SEALs that

2438.71.text:
have put out books and movies,
you become famous after that.

2451.78.text:
you're a well-known hero,
but from the opposition's

2455.48.text:
perspective, you're also a
well-known person who probably

2461.72.text:
they have vowed revenge against
after the various operations

2468.48.text:
AUDIENCE: So how do
you deal with that?

2472.21.text:
That's a tough one because
the realization is there.

2476.09.text:
This mission was so high
profile that the details got out

2481.67.text:
in small circles right
after the mission.

2484.37.text:
We flew out right after it
was over back to Virginia.

2486.86.text:
And by the time we got
back, everybody on both--

2488.86.text:
we have SEAL teams in
Virginia and California--

2491.51.text:
every SEAL knew what
happened and knew the names.

2493.55.text: And then it spread up to DC.

2494.76.text:
I got a call from a friend
who worked in the White House.

2496.37.text:
They knew my name
and all this stuff.

2500.87.text:
There's a lot of different
reasons why you say anything.

2503.21.text:
The book has nothing
to do with this.

2505.73.text:
I believe it was better
to know the threat's real

2508.57.text:
than to stick my head in the
sand and pretend it's not.

2510.86.text:
Because it got out, I was
aware right off the bat

2515.73.text:
I took a lot of security
precautions, with my family,

2519.29.text:
with my kids, and
stuff like that.

2523.68.text:
My kids don't have the
same life they used to.

2526.28.text:
They have more guns and
dogs, which is cool.

2529.25.text: But yes, it's a tough one.

2530.75.text:
But again, coming out with
a story on television,

2536.63.text:
I will assume the
risk if I can, if I

2538.46.text:
need to to help with
the healing process

2540.25.text: because it is such a big thing.

2544.94.text:
It wasn't a one-day decision,
and it's a tough one.

2552.30.text:
AUDIENCE: First of
all, thank you again

2553.53.text: for coming and making the time.

2556.33.text:
AUDIENCE: I had a
question for you.

2557.79.text:
It's seen that online there
were a few other Navy SEALs that

2562.83.text:
were somewhat critical
of you coming out

2564.99.text:
as the individual operator
who killed Osama bin Laden.

2568.62.text:
So I was wondering if
that kind of attitude

2571.35.text:
is widespread amongst the
SEALs, and if you thought--

2579.30.text:
Some of my best times of my
life were in the SEAL teams.

2582.22.text:
What you'll notice
about a lot of people

2583.89.text:
in that, especially get to
the command where I was,

2586.50.text:
the Tier 1 team, everyone
there is such an alpha

2589.44.text:
that they're so used to being
the person that doesn't fail.

2592.51.text:
The way that I put
it with them is,

2593.97.text:
if you took 10 of
those guys and you

2596.40.text:
put a dump truck full of cash
in each one of their driveways,

2599.37.text:
five of them would be pissed
because their drive was

2602.64.text:
They're going to be
mad about something.

2606.57.text:
If they're upset with
me and they served,

2610.50.text: I don't have time for it.

2611.22.text:
I don't think trashing each
other is going to help anybody.

2613.02.text:
If they weren't there,
I don't really care.

2616.92.text: But no, I listen to it.

2619.84.text:
I try to avoid some
of the chat rooms.

2621.42.text: A lot of them are negative.

2622.61.text: A lot of them are positive.

2623.61.text:
I talked to a little
more than half

2624.85.text:
of the guys that
were on the mission.

2629.14.text:
I've never come out and
said, look at me, look at me,

2631.89.text:
It's like, look, I was
part of a great team,

2633.81.text:
got there because
of great people,

2634.92.text:
and great women
showed us where to go.

2636.50.text:
I happened to turn
to the right corner.

2639.49.text:
And I'm just
telling a biography.

2640.89.text:
I mean, none of it's easy, but
that's why they have scotch.

2650.13.text:
AUDIENCE: Part of being
in the military means

2652.05.text:
that you get orders and you kind
of just have to follow them.

2655.56.text:
How do you reconcile
this with the kind

2657.36.text:
of you having your own
opinions or not being

2659.88.text: kind of in agreement with them?

2663.02.text:
ROB O'NEILL: Now, that's
a good question, too.

2665.01.text:
I think what I've
noticed the most is--

2668.69.text:
I worked for President
Clinton, President Bush,

2671.85.text:
and regardless of
your political views

2673.50.text:
or who's in charge, if you
find yourself in a situation

2675.79.text:
where you are dealing
with a defined enemy

2678.09.text:
and we're trying
to kill each other,

2679.59.text:
it no longer becomes
about the politics or even

2681.69.text:
the war effort itself
or the battle space.

2683.73.text:
It becomes about fighting in
that house with my teammates

2688.11.text:
So it's kind of easy
to do it that way.

2689.76.text:
If there's a threat,
I'm going to do

2691.26.text:
what I can to
eliminate the threat,

2692.72.text:
and I'm going to try
to save my teammates.

2695.61.text:
And then the military
is really good about,

2698.43.text:
even in the public
eye, when you're still

2700.14.text:
serving, in uniform,
you're not allowed

2701.61.text:
to express your political views
if you want to on the side.

2704.07.text: So they try to keep it that way.

2708.83.text:
I agreed with a lot of
the stuff that we did.

2710.70.text:
And I think that came because
we had trained for so long

2713.66.text:
to fight before we fight
that it was kind of like,

2715.74.text: I just want to get in the fight.

2717.60.text:
I want a war because
I want to fight.

2718.71.text:
Now, it's like with
the Korea thing,

2720.21.text:
it's like everybody
take a wrap off.

2722.24.text:
Let's not go nuking each
other just because that's

2729.34.text: I hope I answered your question.

2732.86.text:
SPEAKER: I think,
Rob, that brings up

2734.41.text:
another interesting point, the
presence of like social media

2740.68.text:
It's kind of expected that your
service men and women aren't

2744.07.text:
going to go on and post their
opinions politically, right?

2747.94.text:
SPEAKER: Have you ever seen
issues with certain troops

2752.47.text:
People have been
reprimanded and kicked out

2754.26.text: for a lot of social media stuff.

2756.43.text:
Even SEALs get in
trouble for writing books

2758.74.text:
as they're still in the
military, trying to get their--

2761.84.text:
and again, the
social media stuff,

2764.65.text:
But yeah, people do get
in trouble for that.

2767.86.text:
It's a fine line because
yes, they're soldiers,

2772.09.text:
It's not like a video game
where all of a sudden you

2774.31.text:
have these cool guys
that are doing this.

2778.46.text:
They grew up in a certain
place, went to a certain school,

2781.33.text:
And they will have
their beliefs.

2782.21.text:
So they do get in trouble
for a lot of it, too.

2786.46.text:
SPEAKER: So on behalf of Google,
thanks, Rob, for coming out.
